Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Level Data Fusion for Real-Time Prognostic Health Management of Hierarchical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a new real-time prognostics and health management (PHM) methodology for hierarchical engineering systems. This new methodology is based on the fusion of data collected from components and subsystems on different levels of a system. The first effort is to establish an offline model system mathematically integrated from separate component-level survival models, each of which represents the impacts of factors, such as environments and stress, on a component's failure hazard. The offline model system is then incorporated with the online system performance measurements to formulate a state space model that describes the system performance degradation as an observation of conventionally unobservable hazard state evolvement. Based on the state space model, methodologies of online monitoring and prognostics will be developed by combining statistical process control and nonlinear filtering techniques. In addition, real-time decision of maintenance scheduling and resource allocation will be optimally conducted according to the monitoring and prognostics conclusions. These methodologies will be validated and implemented with the real data, case studies and testbed provided by industry supporters.

If successful, the results of this research will advance the state-of-the-art methodologies by contributing new concepts, criteria and algorithms to the course of real-time PHM of hierarchical engineering systems. The developed methodology can be applied to systems that are designed to meet certain highly complex and advanced functional demands in mission-critical industries, such as transportation, energy, infrastructure, and manufacturing. The dissemination of the research results will significantly improve the understanding and prediction of failures of such systems. Consequently, improved real-time PHM practice can be expected, achieving increased system availability and reduced maintenance cost. In addition, the interdisciplinary nature of this collaborative research will benefit students by exposing them to new course modules and research opportunities that involve learning and applying advanced methodologies in reliability, data mining and statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This project developed new methodologies to integrate multi-level, multi-source, multi-type data of hierarchically structured systems with physical structural design knowledge for monitoring, fault diagnosis, and prognosis of such systems. Multi-level hierarchically structured systems commonly exist in many domains such as manufacturing, defense, and infrastructure. Specifically, this project advanced the state of the art research in the following areas: (1) We developed a novel sparse Bayesian network learning algorithm to identify the connectivity and associations of a large number of interacting elements in a system from observational data. This algorithm outperformed existing methods in both accuracy and computational efficiency. This network model allowed further inferring causality and tracing fault propagation in the system and thus providing fundamentals for fault diagnosis and prognosis. (2) We developed a Bayesian fusion framework that was able to aggregate the data at the component-, subsystem-, and system-level in a bottom up manner for effectively predicting system reliability. This framework effectively utilized structural design information of the system, i.e., how the components connect with each other composing a subsystem and how the subsystems connect with each other composing the system, and fuse the design information with imbalanced data collected at multiple levels of the system. Reliability prediction using the proposed framework was shown to have significantly less variability than existing methods. (3) We developed a new methodology to enrich the offline model in (2) with real-time observation data of the system performance as well as environmental variables in order to dynamically update the prognosis in real time. This project produced six journal publications and a number of conference presentations. 

Broader impacts: The research methodology has been applied to a number of application areas including semiconductor manufacturing, mobile communication in defense industry, and health care. Partnerships with these industries have been established. One Ph.D. student was supported and the project also attracted several undergraduate students to participate in the research. The research methodology, real-world datasets, and application case studies have been incorporated into the Quality Control and Advanced Quality Control courses the PI has been teaching.
